newsitem.title: INDIA: Foreign investors cautiously watching India - HSBC.
newsitem.headline: Foreign investors cautiously watching India - HSBC.

text.p: Foreign investors have adopted a wait-and-see attitude due to political uncertainties in India but the overall trend is positive and encouraging, a senior official of HSBC Investment Bank Plc said on Thursday.

"I think there is a desire to invest and they are just taking a wait-and-see attitude before committing themselves," Paul Selway-Swift, chairman of HSBC Investment Bank Asia Holdings Ltd, told Reuters.
"It hasn't given them strong encouragement to invest at this moment," Selway-Swift replied when asked if the recent change in government had affected foreign investment.
Selway-Swift is also deputy chairman of HSBC Investment Bank Plc, part of HSBC Holdings Plc.
Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral assumed office last month after his predecessor H.D. Deve Gowda lost a confidence vote in parliament.
The Congress party withdrew its make-or-break support from Deve Gowda in March but later pledged to back his United Front coalition if Deve Gowda was replaced as leader.
"The economic signals overall are generally positive," Selway-Swift told Reuters after a news conference in the Indian capital.
Foreign investors have confidence in domestic companies and their ability to innovate, work and compete with foreign firms, he added.
HSBC Investment Banking said earlier on Thursday that it is setting up a merchant bank in India.

India's Foreign Investment Promotion Board has approved a $20-million equity investment in HSBC Capital Markets India Private Ltd, making it one of the largest dedicated merchant banks in the country, a company statement said.
It said an application had been submitted to the Securities and Exchange Board of India for a Category One merchant banking licence.
HSBC Investment Banking handles the merchant banking, equity securities and asset management activities of the HSBC group.
HSBC Capital Markets India will specialise in the four products of equity capital markets, debt capital markets, financial advisory including mergers and acquisitions, and project finance.
"We are going to provide the full range of our investment products into the Indian market," Selway-Swift said.
He said foreign investors had shows a great deal of interest in Indian stocks. "There is lot of appetite among international investors for good quality Indian papers," he said.
